channel.title: High Performance Computing Google Group
channel.description: Private discussion group for COMP 388/464, High-Performance Computing.

item.description:
All:

Everyone is invited to attend this and future CJUG presentations (held every
third Tuesday of the month). Free admission for Loyola students, staff and
faculty. (I am serving as the departmental liaison to CJUG.)

item.title: How will Memristors change everything?
item.description:
Very interesting article about newly discovered memristors.

End of the Von Neumann architecture?

[link]

item.title: Any One Interested In An Android Project
item.description:
Well as I have been getting deeper into the Android library, I have begun to
notice a few things.
- I am repeating a lot of code for common tasks(db, barcode, gps,... )
- Common place for instruction is not found (I use google, blogs,
stackoverflow,...)
- Books talk technical not practical of if so not usefully("this is how
item.author: matt...@gmail.com (Matthew Wojtowicz)

item.title: COMP 366/488 needs more students
item.description:
Dear All:
I am writing this e-mail on behalf of Dr. Honig, who is teaching the
Microcomputer Design course next term. Given the significant number of
students who were interested in hardware and hacking in general in this
course, I would like to encourage you to sign up for this course. There are
presently only 8 students enrolled, and in general a course needs 10
item.author: g...@cs.luc.edu (George Thiruvathukal)

item.title: Re: C Question
item.description:
Do you guys know of a way around running a cygwin-built app outside of
cygwin? As I'm sure you know, you get the error "cygwin1.dll is
missing" if you attempt to do so. I'm assuming it isn't possible to
run it outside of cygwin, but if there is a way around it it would be
nice to know.
item.author: sjam...@luc.edu (SteveJMarist)

item.title: Re: C Question
item.description:
Just an update: I sort of combined all of your suggestions for my C
working environment. I'm using Notepad++ for my text editor (thanks
Matthew) and Cygwin and a GCC compiler to compile and run my programs.
Thanks again for your help guys! Happy Holidays.
item.author: sjam...@luc.edu (SteveJMarist)

item.title: Re: C Question
item.description:
Thanks guys! I do actually have Windows 7, so hopefully Joe is right.
I will probably install a few of these things you guys have mentioned
just to check them out.
item.author: sjam...@luc.edu (SteveJMarist)

item.title: Re: C Question
item.description:
It should be fine on Windows 7. I've been using it on my installation for a
bit now.
item.author: joekay...@gmail.com (Joseph Kaylor)

item.title: Re: C Question
item.description:
Steve,
I would recommend that you go to [link] and click on
"Install Cygwin now".
"Cygwin is a Linux-like environment for Windows."
"Note that Windows 7 and later will only be supported starting with
the 1.7 version of Cygwin."
Hopefully you don't have Windows 7.
From the setup program choose the compliers and text editors that you
item.author: luthe...@gmail.com (luther07)

item.title: Re: C Question
item.description:
I'd recommend starting in Linux with GCC and make files. The environment
isn't quite as important when learning a new language.

Here's a good book:
[link]
item.author: joekay...@gmail.com (Joseph Kaylor)

item.title: Re: C Question
item.description:
Notepad ++ is a good text edtior for windows.

For C I would recommend using a gcc to compile your files.

Hey guys, hope everyone is enjoying their winter break so far. I had a
question about something and thought this would be a nice place to get
it out there. With the few weeks we have, I've been inspired by Steve
item.author: matt...@gmail.com (Matthew Wojtowicz)
